item.title: India and Pakistan’s Water Wars Are Just Beginning
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Dan Strumpf

media:content.media:description: A view of a dry path of Indus River in Jamshoro and Kotri district in Hyderabad, Pakistan, on May 6, 2025. Pakistan has warned of a full force response to any attempt by India to divert or block its share of water under the Indus water treaty. (Photo by Jan Ali Laghari / Middle East Images / Middle East Images via AFP) (Photo by JAN ALI LAGHARI/Middle East Images/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: JAN ALI LAGHARI/AFP

item.title: US Fund Managers Put on Notice by $65 Billion Dutch Investor
item.description: Dutch pension fund PME is issuing a blanket warning to US money managers, amid concerns America’s investment industry is caving in to pressure from the Trump administration to abandon basic principles of stewardship.
item.dc:creator: Frances Schwartzkopff

media:content.media:description: President Trump signs executive orders during a ceremony in the Oval Office following the inauguration of his second term.

item.title: Romania’s Georgescu Exits Politics After Ban, Denting Far Right
item.description: Romania’s one-time presidential frontrunner, nationalist Calin Georgescu, said he plans to withdraw from politics, potentially weakening the Black Sea nation’s far-right movement.
item.dc:creator: Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: Calin Georgescu Photographer: Alexandra Corcode/Bloomberg

item.title: Merz Says Kyiv’s Allies Ended Curbs on Russia Strikes Months Ago
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz said Ukraine’s allies decided several months ago to drop restrictions on the use of the weapons they’ve provided to allow Kyiv to strike targets deep inside Russia.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs, Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz speaks during a joint press conference with the Finnish Prime Minister in Turku, Finland, on May 27.

item.title: Reform UK’s Farage to Back Benefit Hikes in Attack on Starmer
item.description: Nigel Farage is extending his bid to win over traditional Labour voters by announcing that his party would scrap a controversial limit on child benefits and fully reinstate utility-bill subsidies for the elderly if it came into power.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage on May 27. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Slovak Premier Rejects Germany’s Warning on Cutting EU Funding
item.description: Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico dismissed a German threat to withhold European Union funding over alleged rule-of-law lapses as unacceptable and contrary to the bloc’s democratic principles.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

media:content.media:description: Slovakia’s Prime Minister Robert Fico. Photographer: Armend Nimani/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Germany Weighs Curbs on Israel Weapons Exports on Gaza Concerns
item.description: Germany is considering restrictions on military exports to Israel over concerns about civilian suffering in Gaza, a notable shift from one of the country’s biggest weapons suppliers.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs, Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: Smoke following an Israeli strike in Jabalia, Gaza Strip on May 25.

item.title: Thailand Clears Plan to Exit US Intellectual Property Watchlist
item.description: Thailand’s cabinet approved a new framework for enforcement of intellectual property rights as the Southeast Asian nation seeks to exit from a US watchlist ahead of tariff talks with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Pathom Sangwongwanich

media:content.media:description: Pichai Naripthaphan Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: China Premier Calls on Asean, Gulf States to Create ‘Big Market’
item.description: Chinese Premier Li Qiang rallied a group of Southeast Asian and Gulf states to deepen cooperation, as the Asian nation ramps up its charm offensive abroad to counter US efforts to isolate the economy.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Kok Leong Chan

media:content.media:description: Li Qiang with leaders at the Asean-GCC-China Summitin Kuala Lumpur on May 27.

item.title: Libyan Peace Push at Risk From Trump Funding Cuts, UN Envoy Says
item.description: Cuts in US funding for the United Nations may hamper efforts to reunite war-torn Libya, where deadly fighting and protests in the capital have sent tensions soaring, a top UN official said.
item.dc:creator: Simon Marks

media:content.media:description: Protesters calling for the resignation of the prime minister block a road in Tripoli on May 25.

item.title: EU to Focus on Critical Sectors in Bid to Avoid Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: The European Union is seeking to accelerate trade talks with the US just six weeks before President Donald Trump’s threatened 50% tariffs come into effect.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Newly manufactured automobiles, wrapped in protective film, on the dockside at the Port of Barcelona in Spain.

item.title: Cerberus Eyes Darwin Port, Australia Reviews Chinese Control
item.description: US private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management LP expressed interest in purchasing the lease for Australia’s strategically important Port of Darwin from Landbridge Group, despite the Chinese firm insisting it has no interest in selling the asset.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott, Sharon Klyne

media:content.media:description: The access entry to the Port of Darwin. Photographer: Darrian Traynor/Getty Images

item.title: Macron Courts Southeast Asia Nations Trapped by US-China Dispute
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron is spearheading the latest effort by European leaders to woo Southeast Asian nations worried about becoming collateral damage in the US trade war and security disputes between Washington and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Samy Adghirni, Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Vietnam’s President Luong Cuong, second right, raises a toast with his French counterpart Emmanuel Macron during a state dinner in Hanoi on May 26.

item.title: Malaysia Stirs ‘Hotpot Diplomacy’ With Palm-Based Fat for China
item.description: Malaysia is seeking to expand its palm oil market in China by offering a plant-based alternative for use in mala hotpot, a popular spicy dish that’s cooked with raw meats and vegetables in a simmering pot.
item.dc:creator: Anuradha Raghu

media:content.media:description: Hotpot in Chongqing. Photographer: Costfoto/NurPhoto/Getty Images

item.title: Japan Government Panel Warns on Rising Yields’ Hit on Finances
item.description: A Japanese government advisory panel urged authorities to step up fiscal consolidation efforts, as the Bank of Japan’s ongoing monetary tightening efforts raise the risk of higher debt-servicing costs for the world’s most indebted developed nation.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Katsunobu Kato

item.title: Malaysia Sees Reducing the US’s Proposed Tariff to 10% as a Good Outcome
item.description: The US reducing its proposed tariffs on Malaysia to a 10% baseline would be seen as a positive move, Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Zafrul Aziz said, conceding that a previously hoped for levy of zero may not be possible.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry, Philip Heijmans, Avril Hong

media:content.media:description: Zafrul Aziz Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: North Korea Says Trump’s Golden Dome Risks ‘Space Nuclear War’
item.description: North Korea sharply criticized President Donald Trump’s plan for a Golden Dome missile-defense system, a shield intended to counter threats from rivals including Pyongyang.
item.dc:creator: Denny Thomas

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump in the Oval Office on May 20. Photographer: Chris Kleponis/CNP/Bloomberg

item.title: Why This River in India and Pakistan Is Causing So Much Angst
item.description: The suspension of a water-sharing agreement in place for 65 years signals a new low in relations between the nations.
item.dc:creator: Ishika Mookerjee, Sonikka Loganathan

media:content.media:description: A view of a dry path of Indus River in Jamshoro and Kotri district in Hyderabad, Pakistan, on May 6, 2025. Pakistan has warned of a full force response to any attempt by India to divert or block its share of water under the Indus water treaty. (Photo by Jan Ali Laghari / Middle East Images / Middle East Images via AFP) (Photo by JAN ALI LAGHARI/Middle East Images/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Bolsonaro’s Son Investigated Over Alleged Court Intimidation
item.description: A Brazilian Supreme Court justice has authorized the federal police to investigate one of the sons of former President Jair Bolsonaro over allegations that he sought to intimidate members of the court while in the US.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Eduardo Bolsonaro Photographer: Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: UK to Train 120,000 Builders, Carers to Cut Reliance on Migrants
item.description: The UK government plans to train 120,000 British builders, engineers and care workers as it tries to curb migration without worsening skill shortages.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: A construction worker carries piping in to a house under construction at a Barratt Developments Plc housing estate in Boroughbridge, UK, on Tuesday, Sept. 10, 2024. The government laid out proposals to boost development this summer, promising to restore mandatory local housebuilding targets that were ditched by the previous Conservative administration.

item.title: Milei Beefs With Netflix Star Over Price of a Dozen Empanadas
item.description: President Javier Milei and his finance chief criticized a globally known Argentine actor for complaining that the country’s staple food was overpriced, stirring debate about how expensive Argentina has become in dollar terms.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Ricardo Darin during an event in Buenos Aires on April 29.

item.title: Israel-Backed Gaza Food Plan Starts Amid Dissent, Delay
item.description: The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, a new Swiss-based nonprofit, said it began distributing food to Palestinians in the war-ravaged Gaza Strip and appointed a new executive director following earlier setbacks.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: Palestinian children at a food point in the Nuseirat refugee camp in central Gaza, on May 24.

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg Loves MAGA Now. Will MAGA Ever Love Him Back?
item.description: Meta’s CEO has done everything he can to win over Trump, and it’s not clear how much he has to show for it.
item.dc:creator: Riley Griffin, Kurt Wagner

media:content.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg says recent changes to Meta’s content policies reflect an authentic representation of his personal views.

item.title: Trump to Pardon Sheriff Found Guilty of ‘Cash-for-Badges’ Scheme
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would be pardoning a former Virginia sheriff facing a 10-year prison sentence after being convicted of bribery and fraud charges.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump speaks during the Memorial Day wreath-laying ceremony in Arlington National Cemetery on May 26, 2025.

item.title: King Charles Visits Canada as Country Rattled by Trump Taunts
item.description: King Charles III arrived in Canada to open a new parliamentary session at the invitation of Prime Minister Mark Carney, a move designed in part to send a message to US President Donald Trump about the northern country’s sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: King Charles III and Queen Camilla arrive at Ottawa Airport on Monday.

item.title: Multiple People Taken to Hospitals After Shooting Incident in South Carolina Beach Town
item.description: LITTLE RIVER, S.C. (AP) — Ten people were shot during a fight that started after a private boat hosting a holiday weekend party arrived at a dock Sunday night on the South Carolina coast, authorities said.

item.title: South Korean Election: Can a New President Bring Back Stability?
item.description: South Koreans are set to finally choose a new president after the nation’s worst constitutional crisis in decades.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Election banners displayed in Seoul. Photographer: Tina Hsu/Bloomberg

item.title: Charles Rangel, a Voice for the Poor in Tax Debates, Dies at 94
item.description: Charles Rangel, the dapper, voluble US congressman from New York’s Harlem district who for four decades used his perch on the House tax-writing committee to advocate for inner cities and the people who live there, has died. He was 94.
item.dc:creator: Laurence Arnold

media:content.media:description: Charles Rangel in 2014.

item.title: Macron Says Shoving Incident on Plane Was Him and Wife ‘Joking’
item.description: PARIS (AP) — They were just playfighting.

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, France's president, at the Elysee Palace in Paris, France, on Monday, June 24, 2024. In the days after Macron’s surprise call for an election to renew the National Assembly two weeks ago, his allies have taken to the air waves to speak of the dangers of the far right or the far left coming into power. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

item.title: Chile’s Leftist Presidential Hopefuls Spar Over SQM-Codelco Deal
item.description: Chile’s left-leaning presidential contenders clashed over a landmark deal signed last year between lithium supplier SQM and state-owned Codelco, highlighting differences ahead of the sector’s primary vote.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Jeannette Jara speaks to members of the media after registering her candidacy in Santiago on April 30.
